skill.name: react-19-patterns
skill.description: Comprehensive React 19 patterns including all hooks, Server/Client Components, Suspense, streaming, and transitions. Ensures correct React 19 usage with TypeScript.
skill.summary: Comprehensive React 19 patterns including all hooks, Server/Client Components, Suspense, streaming, ...
skill.author: Barnhardt-Enterprises-Inc

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation skill containing markdown guides and a validation tool for React 19 patterns. All 747 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The detected patterns are markdown inline code formatting (backticks), code examples in documentation, and legitimate React patterns showing best practices.

content.value_statement: Writing React 19 components requires understanding Server vs Client patterns, new hooks, and Suspense boundaries. This skill provides comprehensive guides and a validation tool to ensure correct React 19 usage with TypeScript.
actual_capabilities: Guides for Server vs Client Component decisions with decision trees
Complete reference for all React 19 hooks with TypeScript examples
Suspense patterns with streaming, fallbacks, and error boundaries
Transitions guide for useTransition, startTransition, and isPending
Migration guide from React 18 to React 19 with breaking changes explained
validate-react.py tool to check React code for common mistakes
limitations: Does not install dependencies or create project files
Does not execute React code or run tests
Does not provide runtime error handling or debugging
Does not generate new components from scratch

use_cases.title: Learn React 19 patterns
use_cases.description: Understand when to use Server vs Client Components and apply new React 19 hooks correctly.

use_cases.title: Migrate to React 19
use_cases.description: Follow the migration guide to update React 18 codebases with breaking changes explained.

use_cases.title: Validate React code
use_cases.description: Use the validation tool to catch Rules of Hooks violations and component mistakes automatically.

prompt_templates.title: Component decisions
prompt_templates.prompt: Should I use a Server or Client Component for a component that needs useState and onClick handlers?

prompt_templates.title: New hooks usage
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I use useOptimistic to show instant feedback when adding items to a list?

prompt_templates.title: Suspense patterns
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to use Suspense boundaries with streaming data fetching in React 19.

prompt_templates.title: Migration help
prompt_templates.prompt: What are the breaking changes when migrating from React 18 to React 19? Give examples.

output_examples.input: Create a component that fetches data and displays it
output: Server Components are ideal for data fetching. Use async/await directly. Pass data as props to Client Components for interactivity.
Example: async function DataPage() { const data = await db.query(); return <ClientList items={data} /> }

output_examples.input: How do I prevent blocking user input during heavy updates?
output: Use useTransition to mark expensive updates as non-urgent. This keeps input responsive while React processes the updates in the background.

output_examples.input: Why is my Client Component throwing an error?
output: Common causes: missing 'use client' directive, using async function export, or calling browser APIs in Server Components. Run validate-react.py to identify the issue.

best_practices: Default to Server Components for better performance and smaller bundles
Use Client Components only for interactivity requiring hooks or event handlers
Keep Client Components small by composing them within Server Components
anti_patterns: Using async/await in Client Components (not allowed without special handling)
Calling hooks inside conditions, loops, or nested functions (Rules of Hooks violation)
Using browser APIs like localStorage in Server Components (causes hydration errors)

faq.question: When should I use Server vs Client Components?
faq.answer: Use Server Components for data fetching, SEO content, and static UI. Use Client Components for interactivity, hooks, and browser APIs.

faq.question: What are the new React 19 hooks?
faq.answer: use() for async data, useOptimistic() for instant feedback, useFormStatus() for form states, and useActionState() for Server Actions.

faq.question: How do I handle loading states?
faq.answer: Use Suspense boundaries with fallback components. React 19 streaming allows progressive HTML delivery while data loads.

faq.question: Can I use async components in React 19?
faq.answer: Yes, Server Components can be async by default. Client Components cannot be async but can use useEffect for async operations.

faq.question: How do I validate my React code?
faq.answer: Run the validate-react.py tool: python validate-react.py src/components/ checks for Rules of Hooks, component mistakes, and more.

faq.question: What is the migration path from React 18?
faq.answer: Key changes include: async Client Components not allowed, new hook behaviors, Suspense in data fetching, and updated ref patterns.
